content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</origin>         <pubdate>20141209</pubdate>         <title>Terrestrial Environmental Observation Network (TEON) Nested Watershed Boundaries, 2014.</title>         <edition>Edition 2.0, 2014</edition>         <geoform>Vector Digital Data Set (Polygon)</geoform>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Fairbanks, Alaska</pubplace>           <publish>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink>http://arcticlcc.org/projects/teon/teon-spatial-data/show/teon-focal-watersheds-and-observation-sites-gis-data</onlink>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract>The Terrestrial Environmental Observation Network (TEON) is an effort to establish a sustainable environmental observing network of northern Alaska.  TEON will focus work in watersheds that collectively represent the diversity of landscape settings at the ecoregional scale, take advantage of existing science infrastructure and logistics capacity, and provide opportunities to build on existing long-term data sets. Candidate watersheds for TEON include Agashashok River, Barrow/Meade River, Fish/Judy Creek, Hulahula River, Kokolik River, Kuparuk River, and Upper Koyukuk River.</abstract>       <purpose>These polygons represent the the approximate boundaries of the nested watersheds within the TEON network.</purpose>       <supplinf>More information about TEON can be found at: http://arcticlcc.org/projects/teon/.</supplinf>     </descript>     <timeperd>       <timeinfo>         <sngdate>           <caldate>20141209</caldate>         </sngdate>       </timeinfo> Although the data have been gathered by sources believed to be reliable, Arctic LCC neither verifies nor guarantees the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data.</logic>     <complete>This dataset represents the approximate boundaries of the TEON watersheds.</complete>     <posacc>       <horizpa>         <horizpar>A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.</horizpar>       </horizpa>       <vertacc>         <vertaccr>A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.</vertaccr>       </vertacc>     </posacc>     <lineage>       <srcinfo>         <srccite>           <citeinfo>             <origin>U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), EROS Data Center</origin>             <pubdate>1999</pubdate>             <title>National Elevation Dataset</title>             <geoform>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</geoform>             <pubinfo>               <pubplace>Sioux Falls, SD</pubplace>               <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>             </pubinfo>           </citeinfo>         </srccite>         <typesrc>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</typesrc>         <srctime>           <timeinfo>             <sngdate>               <caldate>1999</caldate>             </sngdate>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>NED 30M</srccitea>         <srccontr>Source information used in support of the development of the data set.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <srcinfo>         <srccite>           <citeinfo>             <origin>B.M. Jones and G. Grosse, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Geophysical Institute Permafrost Laboratory.</origin>             <pubdate>2013</pubdate>             <title>Western Arctic Coastal Plain, IFSAR-derived, Digital Surface Model.  University of Alaska Fairbanks, Geophysical Institute Permafrost Laboratory (2013).</title>             <geoform>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</geoform>             <pubinfo>               <pubplace>Fairbanks, Alaska</pubplace>               <publish>Arctic Landscape Conservation Cooperative</publish>             </pubinfo>           </citeinfo>         </srccite>         <typesrc>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</typesrc>         <srctime>           <timeinfo>             <sngdate>               <caldate>2002</caldate>             </sngdate>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>ground condition</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>IfSAR DEM 5m</srccitea>         <srccontr>Source information used in support of the development of the data set.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <procstep>         <procdesc>Boundaries for the watersheds, with the exception of Nunavak Creek, are derived from the National Elevation Dataset (NED) - 1 arc-second (approximately 30 meters).  Nunavak Creek watershed boundary was derived from Western Arctic Coastal Plane (WACP) IfSAR-derived DSM (5 m).Step 1: Use the Fill (Spatial Analyst) tool in ArcGIS 10.2 to remove cells identified as sinks.  Note that peaks were not removed.Step 2: Use the Flow Direction (Spatial Analyst) tool in ArcGIS 10.2 to determine the direct of flow from the cells in the raster.Step 3: Use the Flow Accumulation (Spatial Analyst) tool in ArcGIS 10.2 to identify areas of high flow accumulation in order to identify stream channels.Step 4: Use the Watershed (Spatial Analyst) tool in ArcGIS 10.2 to identify the areas that are upstream of the potential stations.Step 5: Use the Raster to Polygon (Conversion) tool in ArcGIS 10.2 to convert the watershed raster dataset into polygon features.  The resulting polygons were not simplified.</procdesc>         <procdate>2014</procdate>       </procstep>     </lineage>   </dataqual>   <spdoinfo>     <direct>Vector</direct>     <ptvctinf>
